conclusion: To determine if point O1 is to the right of point O, apply principles of refraction, specifically Snell's Law.
Understand refraction: Light bends towards the normal when going from a less dense medium to a denser medium.
Identify the normal: An imaginary line perpendicular to the boundary at the point where the light ray crosses.

The light beam starts from point A in the air, travels along direction AO1, enters the water at point O1, and passes through point B in the water. Point O is the intersection of line AB and the boundary.
Apply Snell's Law: Incident ray is AO1 and refracted ray is O1B. If no refraction, light would travel directly from A to B along line AB.
When light goes from air to water, it bends towards the normal. Refracted ray O1B must be closer to the normal than incident ray AO1.
If O1 were to the left of O, the angle of refraction would be larger than the angle of incidence, contradicting the law of refraction.
For light to bend towards the normal and pass through point B, point of incidence O1 must be to the right of point O.
Conclusion: Yes, point O1 is to the right of point O.
